content.question: A brick is dropped from the top of a building and falls toward the ground. In Case <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, the brick lands on concrete and breaks into many pieces. In Case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, the brick lands on a thin foam pad and does not break. Why does the brick not break in Case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> but breaks in Case <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>?

choices.label: Because the foam pad reduces the impulse applied to the brick to stop it.
Because the foam pad reduces the work done on the brick to stop it.
Because the foam pad increases the magnitude of the force applied on the brick to stop it.
Because the foam pad increases the time that the force is applied to the brick to stop it.

content.answer: Because the foam pad increases the time that the force is applied to the brick to stop it.
